This study investigates the effectiveness of x Ni – (5 – x) Co / 5 Pd – Al2O3 (where x=0, 1.25, 2.5, 3.75, and 5) bimetallic catalysts and the influence of the Pd on their activity in the dry reforming of methane. Comprehensive characterization techniques including XRD, TPR, TPD, SEM, TGA, and Raman analysis are employed to examine the catalysts. XRD analysis of the calcined catalysts reveals the presence of multiple oxides such as NiO, CoO, Co3O4, and PdO. The metal-support interaction and the particle sintering of the catalysts depend on the amount of Co loading, for higher Co loadings (> 2.5 wt%) resulted in weakened metal-support interaction as indicated by TPR analysis. Also, the particle sintering was observed with an increase in Co loading observed from SEM and TEM analysis. The activity analysis demonstrates that the 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalysts exhibit superior performance in terms of both CH4 (59%) and CO2 (64%) conversions, as well as stability, compared to the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst. The addition of Co leads to decreased activity, Furthermore, TGA analysis indicates minimal carbon deposition on the 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalyst during the 7-hour activity study. Notably, Raman analysis reveals a lower presence of graphitic carbon on the catalyst, which contributes to its stable catalytic activity. The presence of Pd in the 5 Ni catalyst reduces carbon deposition and enhances its activity. However, in the case of the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst, the promotional effect of Pd appears to be negligible. Overall, these findings emphasize the promising potential of the 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalyst for efficient and stable dry reforming of methane. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni-Co, Bi-metallic, DRM Metal support interaction Carbon Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM), discovered by Fischer and Tropsch in 1928, has garnered significant attention as a means of producing energy from greenhouse gasses such as CH4 and CO2. The syngas generated through DRM can be utilized to produce liquid fuels like methanol and dimethyl ether via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis process. The DRM reaction occurs at high temperatures (> 700°C) over a catalyst surface, typically made up of noble (Pt, Pd, Ru, and Rh) or non-noble (Ni, Co, and Fe) metals [1,2]. Despite its significant energy production potential, the DRM process has yet to be commercialized due to severe catalyst deactivation caused by carbon deposition. Due to the high occurrence and cost-effectiveness, Ni-based catalysts are highly employed in DRM [3,4]. However, Ni-based catalysts can deactivate at higher temperatures due to sintering and carbon deposition. Various strategies have been employed to improve the stability of Ni catalysts for DRM. This includes changing preparation methods and optimizing synthesis conditions such as calcination temperature and time [5–7]. Another strategy is using various modifiers such as MgO, La2O3, CeO2, and ZrO2. These have been shown to improve the stability and activity of the Ni catalysts' by enhancing the dispersion, decreasing carbon deposition, and improving the resistance to the sintering [8–10]. Employing different structured catalysts is another promising approach to improve the stability of Ni catalysts [11,12]. Core-shell catalysts, for example, have a core of a highly stable material such as Al2O3, which protects the Ni active sites from deactivation due to carbon deposition [13]. Hydrotalcite catalysts, on the other hand, have a layered structure that promotes the dispersion of the active metal and prevents the sintering [14]. Perovskite oxide catalysts have also been shown to have excellent stability due to their high structural stability and resistance to carbon deposition [12,15]. Recently, bi-metallic catalysts displayed high stability Ni catalysts owing to the synergetic effect of Ni-M (M: Pt, Pd, Ru, Co, Fe, In and Cu) alloy phases, which reduces the active metal sintering and carbon deposition on Ni catalysts, resulting enhanced catalytic activity [14,16–18]. For instance, Wang et al. [17] developed coke-resistant 3 Ni- 2 In/Al2O3 bi-metallic catalysts for DRM at 700 °C. Ni catalysts showed stable activity with CH4 and CO2 conversions of 91% and 97%, respectively, on time on stream of 200 h for a CH4/CO2 ratio of 1.0. In improved the Ni dispersion from 8% (Ni/Al2O3) to 21% (3 Ni-2 In/Al2O3). Also, it decreased the acid sites of Al2O3, which played an important role in CO2 activation and improved CO2 conversions, and reduced carbon deposition on the bi-metallic catalyst. A similar observation was reported for the addition of Co to Ni catalyst [14,19]. Rahemi et al. [20] found superior catalyst performance of Co-promoted catalyst (than Cu-promoted catalyst) over Ni/Al2O3 due to smaller Ni particle size, higher Ni/Al ratio, and more uniform surface. Wu et al. [21] discussed the enhanced dissociation of CO2 as well as weak chemosorption of H2 over the Ni-Co alloy phase at alumina. For instance, Duan et al. [14] prepared Ni-Co/Mg-Al catalysts using hydrotalcite and tested them for CO2 reforming. Authors observed reduced carbon deposition and displayed stable catalytic activity with CH4, and CO2 conversions are 84% and 91%, respectively, at 750 °C. The incorporation of Co improved the adsorption of CO2, as revealed from CO2 TPD, which enhanced carbon gasification during DRM. Few studies investigated the addition of Pd to improve the activity of the Ni-based catalysts, Ni-Pd catalysts exhibit higher carbon tolerance and high activity than the monometallic Ni and Pd catalysts [22–24]. Pan et al. [15]. showed Pd promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst had a larger fraction of exposed active Nio sites with enhanced dispersion. From the literature survey, it can be concluded that incorporating Pd and Co in Ni/Al2O3 catalyst must bring higher catalytic stability, enhanced Ni dispersion and coke tolerance towards the DRM. In this study, we developed an x Ni - (5-x) Co/5 Pd-Al2O3 (x: 0, 1.25, 2.5, 3.75, and 5) bi-metallic catalyst prepared using wet impregnation and characterized using various techniques such as XRD, TPR, TPD, BET, and TGA to study the structural, metal support interaction, basicity, surface area and carbon deposition. All the catalysts are studied for DRM at 700°C for 7h. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst Preparation The catalysts are prepared using the wet-impregnation method, the catalyst precursors such as nickel nitrate hexahydrate [Ni (NO3)26H2O; 98%, Alfa Aesar] and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate [Co (NO3)26H2O;99%, Alfa Aesar] are dissolved in distilled water and stirred continuously to form a uniform solution. Thereafter, catalyst support (5wt.% Pd+Al2O3; powder, Sigma-Aldrich Chem. Co. USA) is added to the precursor solution. Impregnated catalysts are dried for 12h at 120°C and followed by 600°C calcination for 3h. The series of catalysts are labeled as x Ni - (5 – x) Co /5 Pd - Al2O3, where x=0, 1.25, 2.5, 3.75, and 5. 2.2 Catalyst, Performance Evaluation The DRM performance of the catalysts is evaluated at a reaction temperature of 700°C at 1 atm pressure. Experiments are carried out in a packed bed stainless steel reactor (internal diameter of 0.91mm and a length of 30cm). The reactor is packed with 0.10g of catalyst which is supported on glass wool. The temperature during the reaction is monitored using a K-type, stainless steel sheathed thermocouple, which is axially positioned near the catalyst bed. Before the reaction, catalyst activation was performed using H2 at 700°C for 60 min, followed by purging residual H2 with N2. The flow rates of the gasses (CH4, CO2, and N2) are maintained at a volume ratio of 3:3:1 and have a space velocity of 42,000 ml/gcat.h during the reaction. The gas composition of the outlet stream from the reactor was analyzed online using a Gas Chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The CH4 and CO2 conversions are calculated using the equations given below C H 4 C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = C H 4 , i n − C H 4 , o u t C H 4 , i n × 100 C O 2 C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = C O 2 , i n − C O 2 , o u t C O 2 , i n × 100 2.3 Catalyst characterization The prepared catalysts are studied using X-ray diffraction (XRD) miniflex diffractometer having Cu Kα radiation (Rigaku Corporation, The Woodlands, TX, USA) to understand the phases present in the catalyst. The instrument is operated at 40 KV and 40 mA from 5 to 90° at a scanning rate of 2 deg/ min. The AutoChem II 2920 unit by Micromeritics is utilized to measure the reducibility of calcined catalysts. For the analysis, 0.07 g of the sample is placed in the sampler holder and heated under pure argon at 150°C for 30 min, after which it is cooled to room temperature. The temperature is then increased from 25°C to 900°C at a rate of 10 K/min while being exposed to a 10% H2/Ar mixture at a flow rate of 40 ml/min. The volume of H2 outlet is measured using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) detector. The temperature-programmed CO2 desorption (CO2-TPD) is measured using automatic chemisorption equipment, the Micromeritics Autochem II 2920, which also has a TCD detector. For this analysis, 50 mg of the sample is heated at 200°C for an hour under a helium flow to remove any adsorbed components and then cooled to room temperature. CO2 adsorption is carried out at 50°C for 60 min in a gas mixture of helium and CO2 at a flow rate of 30 ml/min. The TCD records the CO2 desorption signals as the temperature is raised to 900°C at a rate of 10 K/min. The surface morphology of the catalysts is studied using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-7100 F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL, JEM-1400, 120 kV) analysis. Prior to the TEM analysis, a few mg of the sample is dissolved in ethanol and subjected to ultrasonication to get a uniform suspension followed by dropping the suspension on the Cu grid for imaging. To measure the amount of carbon deposition on the spent catalysts, Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA-51 by Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan), is used, in this analysis, 10–20 mg of the spent catalyst is heated in the presence of nitrogen at a rate of 20°C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD Fig. 1 displays the XRD analysis of calcined catalysts at 600°C for 3h. The XRD analysis of the calcined catalysts indicates the presence of multiple phases, including γ-Al2O3, NiO, CoO, PdO, Co3O4, NiAl2O4, and CoAl2O4 [25,26]. The Co and Ni aluminates have resulted, during the calcination due to the reaction between CoO and NiO with the Al2O3 support [25,27]. A strong γ-Al2O3 peak is visible for all catalysts at 67° and 85.1° (PDF: 1,010,461). Metal oxide phases such as PdO can be observed at 34.49°, 42.62°, 46.2°, and 72.8° (PDF:1,011,329), while NiO (PDF:1,010,381) and CoO (PDF: 1,528,838) are present at 36.99° and 42.2°, respectively. In addition, Co3O4 (PDF:1,538,531) is also evident in all catalysts at 30.9°, 37.1°, 45.7°, 55°, 64.8°, and 78.7°, as depicted in the Fig. 1. However, because of the overlapping of the diffraction pattern of NiO with CoO and CoO with Co3O4, it is difficult to distinguish between the individual presence of these oxides. Similar overlapping of the XRD phases of NiO, CoO and Co3O4 was reported by Liu et al. [26] for Ni-Co/Al2O3 catalysts for DRM. Also, both CoAl2O4 (PDF: 9,005,203) and NiAl2O4 (PDF:9,001,432) are overlapped at 30.8°, 37.1°, 45.5°, 59.7°, 64.8°, 71°, and 78.7°, respectively, for all the catalysts. Nevertheless, the individual peak visible at 19.5° confirms the presence of NiAl2O4 in all the catalysts. 3.2 TPR The metal support interaction is studied using H2 TPR as shown in the Fig. 2. Depending on the (5-x) Ni – x (Co)/5 Pd - Al2O3 bi-metallic composition various reduction peaks are observed from 100 °C to 900 °C. The 5 Co/Pd-Al2O3 catalyst displayed three reduction peaks at 200 °C, 400 °C and 780 - 870 °C that pertain to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, CoO to Co0 and Co° from CoAl2O4 [28,29]. In the case of pure Ni catalyst (5 Ni/5Pd-Al2O3), two small reduction peaks have appeared at 500°C, 550°C and one broad reduction peak observed at 850°C related to the reduction of Ni° from NiO and NiAl2O4 respectively [30]. The addition of Co to Ni decreased the metal support interaction, which shifted the reduction peaks to lower temperatures as shown in Fig. 2. For instance, 3.75 Ni – 1.25 Co, 2.5 Ni – 2.5 Co and 1.25 Ni – 3.75 Co catalysts displayed low-temperature reduction peaks at 410 °C, 390 °C, and 380 °C related to the reduction of both Co0 and Ni° from CoO and NiO. Additionally, both 2.5 Ni – 2.5 Co and 1.25 Ni – 3.75 Co catalysts displayed a reduction peak at 120 °C related to the reduction of Pd and CoO from PdO and Co3O4. The order of metal support interaction of the catalysts is observed to be 1.25 Ni – 3.75 Co/5 Pd – Al2O3 < 5 Co/5 Pd – Al2O3 < 2.5 Ni – 2.5 Co/ 5 Pd – Al2O3 < 3.75 Ni – 1.25 Co/5 Pd – Al2O3 < 5 Ni/ 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalysts respectively. 3.3 TPD The basicity of the catalysts is measured using CO2 TPD analysis as displayed in the Fig. 3. Depending on the CO2 desorption temperature, basic sites are categorized into weak, medium, strong and very strong [31]. All the catalysts displayed similar desorption peaks ranging from 100 °C to 700 °C. The addition of Co has slightly shifted the TPD peaks towards the right and it is observed that very strong desorption peaks appeared for the catalysts having high Co content (3.75 wt% and 5 wt%). This is due to the increase in the extent of CO2 interaction upon Co addition. Similar TPD peaks were observed for Ni-Co/Al2O3 catalysts [26]. 3.4 SEM analysis The effect of adding Co to the Ni catalyst was investigated by analyzing the surface morphology using SEM analysis, as depicted in the Fig. 4 . The particle size of the catalysts was determined using Image J analysis, resulting in values of 3.3 µm, 3.8 µm, and 3 µm for the 2.5 Ni – 2.5 Co, 5 Co, and 5 Ni catalysts, respectively. The observed increase in particle size upon Co addition can be attributed to a weakened metal-support interaction. Furthermore, for the spent catalyst, it was observed that the 2.5 Ni and 5 Co catalysts exhibited higher levels of particle agglomeration compared to the 5 Ni catalyst. Quantitatively, the particle size was calculated to be 11.6 µm, 6.8 µm, and 5 µm, respectively, for the catalysts. These findings suggest that the addition of Co has a significant impact on the catalyst's surface morphology. 3.5 TEM analysis The surface morphology of the catalysts was further studied with transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis as shown in Fig. 5 both reduced and spent catalysts. The addition of Co, for instance, the catalyst composition of 2.5 Ni - 2.5 Co resulted in increased particle agglomeration compared to the monometallic Ni catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 5a and b. This observation suggests that the presence of Co influences the catalyst's structural properties, leading to enhanced particle clustering. Additionally, upon analyzing the spent catalyst, it was found that the 5 Ni catalysts exhibited negligible carbon deposition. In contrast, the 2.5 Ni - 2.5 Co catalyst displayed carbon nanotubes on its surface. Interestingly, the carbon growth on the catalyst surface was observed to be tip-grown carbon, as illustrated in Fig. 5. d, specifically for the Co-loaded catalyst. The TEM analysis is clearly in agreement with the SEM analysis as described above. The larger particle size observed for the 2.5 Ni and 5 Co catalysts, both before and after the reaction, implies a less stable metal-support interaction which is confirmed by the TPR analysis as discussed above. In contrast, the 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalyst maintained a smaller particle size, indicating a stronger metal-support interaction, which likely contributes to its enhanced stability during the DRM process. 3.6 Catalysts activity The initial conversions of both CH4 and CO2 are decreased with the addition of Co from 0 wt% to 5 wt% from 60% to 45% and 67% to 53% for all the catalysts is shown in the Fig. 6 . The increase in Co composition from 2.5 wt% to 3.75 wt% and 5 wt% has significantly decreased the activity of the catalysts due to the decrease in metal support interaction which is confirmed with the low-temperature TPR peaks as described earlier. For all the catalyst combinations the conversion of CO2 is found to be higher than CH4 conversion due to possible reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS: CO2+H2⇔ CO+H2) at 700°C [26]. Due to RWGS, the H2/CO ratio for all the catalysts is observed to be less than one for all the catalysts shown in Fig. 6. Based on the activity studies, it is observed that the addition of Co to Ni did not help much in the catalytic activity. Among all the bi-metallic compositions, the best possible conversions appeared for the 2.5 Ni – 2.5 Co combination with CH4 and CO2 conversions of 55% and 63% respectively. A similar decrease in activity was observed in other studies [19,26]. For instance Bian et al. [19] observed a decrease in the catalytic activity of Ni/SiO2 catalysts with the addition of Co for DRM. Authors observed a decline in conversions of CH4 and CO2 from 85% to 45% with the addition of 5 wt% Co. The decrease in activity was attributed to the formation of Ni-Co alloy and also the coverage of Ni active sites by Co. The high activity of the 5 Ni catalysts is attributed to the strong metal support interaction and negligible carbon deposition on the catalyst surface as revealed from spent catalyst analysis of TEM and TGA analysis. The experimental conversions for all the catalysts obtained in this study are observed to be below the equilibrium conversion values (CH4 = 90% and CO2 = 66%) for DRM at 700°C at 1 atm pressure [32]. Additionally, the obtained conversions are found to be higher than the existing conversions reported on the bi-metallic catalysts as mentioned in Table 1 . 3.7 TGA The spent catalysts are studied using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) to determine the carbon deposition. The carbon deposition on the catalysts is calculated to be 1, 6.88, 2.9, 3.12, and 2.9 mg for 5 Ni, 3.75 Ni - 1.25 Co, 2.5 Ni – 2.5 Co, 1.25 Ni – 3.75 Co, and 5 Co catalysts respectively. Among all the catalysts studied 5 Ni/5 Pd – Al2O3 displayed the least amount of carbon deposition (3 wt%) as shown in the Fig. 7 . The presence of Pd decreased the carbon deposition on the catalyst. A similar decrease in carbon deposition of Ni-Pd catalysts was observed in the DRM studies [22–24]. The addition of Co to Ni has a dual effect on the amount of carbon deposition on the catalyst, for instance, at the low composition of Co (1.25 wt%), the carbon deposition was 87%. Furthermore, with an increase in Co content from 1.25 to 5 wt%, there is a significant drop in carbon deposition from 87 wt% to 15 wt%. 3.8 Raman analysis Raman analysis is a useful technique for studying the structural forms of carbon that deposit on the surface of a spent catalyst in DRM. Two main forms of carbon can be identified using this method: amorphous and graphitic. Amorphous carbon is highly reactive and can be easily gasified during the DRM process. In contrast, graphitic carbon is relatively inert and often leads to catalyst deactivation by blocking active sites on the surface. Depending on the Raman shift values, the carbon formed in DRM is classified as defective carbon or amorphous carbon (D-band:1360 cm−1) and graphitic carbon (G-band: 1590 cm−1) [31,37]. Additionally, the intensity ratio of the D – band (ID) to G – band (IG) provides the defective nature of the carbon, if the ID/IG ratio is high, then the carbon deposited on the catalyst surface is highly defective carbon. The order of defective carbon (ID/IG) on the spent catalyst is varied depending on the bi-metallic compositions and is calculated to be 2.24, 1.34, 2.05, 1.47, and 0.91 for 5 Ni, 3.75 Ni – 1.25 Co, 2.5 Ni – 2.5 Co, 1.25 Ni – 3.75 Co and 5 Co catalysts respectively. Among all the catalysts 5 Ni / 5 Pd - Al displayed less graphitic carbon on the catalyst surface, and this makes the catalyst highly active and stable during DRM. A similar type of carbon (defective, ID/IG = 2.3) was observed for Ni – Pd catalysts in DRM at 700°C [22]. On the other hand, the 5 Co/5 Pd – Al2O3 catalyst displayed high graphitic carbon on the catalyst surface thus leading to rapid catalyst deactivation and poor activity as discussed in the activity analysis (Fig. 8 ). 4 Conclusions • A Series of catalysts with compositions of x Ni – (5 – x) Co/ 5 Pd – Al2O3 (x=0, 1.25, 2.5, 3.75, and 5) catalysts are prepared using the wet impregnation method and tested for DRM at 700°C for 7h. • XRD results show the presence of multiple oxides (Al2O3, NiO, CoO, and PdO) as well as aluminate phases (NiAl2O4 and CoAl2O4). • Overlapping of NiO with CoO and CoO with Co3O4, it is difficult to distinguish between the individual presence of these oxides, which is a similar case with NiAl2O4 and CoAl2O4. • The presence of these oxides is further confirmed with the low temperature (< 400 °C) and high temperature (> 700 °C) TPR peaks. • The addition of Co led to increased basicity of the catalysts and slightly shifted the TPD peaks to a higher temperature, however, this addition did not exert a significant influence on the activity of the catalysts. • The TPR analysis of the bi-metallic catalysts (Ni-Co) revealed a decrease in metal support interaction with the increase in Co loading from 0 wt.% to 5wt.%. Moreover, the SEM and TEM analysis displayed the catalysts’ particle size increase with an increase in Co amount. • Among all the catalysts studied 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 displayed stable catalytic activity for 7h. The order of catalytic activity is observed to be 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 > 2.5 Ni – 2.5 Co / 5 Pd – Al2O3 > 3. 75 Ni – 1.25 Co / 5 Pd – Al2O3 > 1.25 Ni – 3.75 Co / 5 Pd – Al2O3 > 5 Co / 5 Pd – Al2O3. • The TGA analysis of spent catalysts indicated a negligible amount of carbon deposition on the 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalyst which is in line with the TEM analysis of spent catalysts. • Furthermore, Raman analysis revealed the presence of highly defective carbon on the catalyst surface, which contributes to its high activity and stability in the DRM process. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the effectiveness of x Ni – (5 – x) Co / 5 Pd – Al2O3 (where x=0, 1.25, 2.5, 3.75, and 5) bimetallic catalysts and the influence of the Pd on their activity in the dry reforming of methane. Comprehensive characterization techniques including XRD, TPR, TPD, SEM, TGA, and Raman analysis are employed to examine the catalysts. XRD analysis of the calcined catalysts reveals the presence of multiple oxides such as NiO, CoO, Co3O4, and PdO. The metal-support interaction and the particle sintering of the catalysts depend on the amount of Co loading, for higher Co loadings (> 2.5 wt%) resulted in weakened metal-support interaction as indicated by TPR analysis. Also, the particle sintering was observed with an increase in Co loading observed from SEM and TEM analysis. The activity analysis demonstrates that the 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalysts exhibit superior performance in terms of both CH4 (59%) and CO2 (64%) conversions, as well as stability, compared to the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst. The addition of Co leads to decreased activity, Furthermore, TGA analysis indicates minimal carbon deposition on the 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalyst during the 7-hour activity study. Notably, Raman analysis reveals a lower presence of graphitic carbon on the catalyst, which contributes to its stable catalytic activity. The presence of Pd in the 5 Ni catalyst reduces carbon deposition and enhances its activity. However, in the case of the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst, the promotional effect of Pd appears to be negligible. Overall, these findings emphasize the promising potential of the 5 Ni / 5 Pd – Al2O3 catalyst for efficient and stable dry reforming of methane.
